Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks to elucidate the behavior of self-propelled Janus particles near interfaces, using molecular dynamics to examine the countervailing influences of Brownian motion, solute concentration gradient, motion-induced fluid flow, and asymmetric force fields. The PI?s divide the main responsibilities according to their experimental and theoretical affiliations, but there are also collaborations with other laboratories in other universities for other techniques (e.g. using colloidal probe atomic force microscopy). The research plan bridges the gap between atomic-level simulations and colloidal-scale modeling and is very innovative and challenging. The results of such an investigation should have broad applications in mixing, assembling, and transport of particles in complex fluids and microfluidic devices.
The broader impacts on potential development of active materials in the formulation and directed self-assembly of designer materials, and the use of self-propelled particles in lab-on-a-chip type devices for cargo and drug delivery are very good as is the potential impact of their outreach to underrepresented college-level students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research goal of the NSF-CBET 1264550 grant was to investigate the motion of Janus and patchy particles, i.e., spherical particles with two distinct surface portions – asymmetric particles, near a liquid/solid and a fluid/fluid interface using experimental techniques and simulation tools. Most importantly, the orientation of these asymmetric particles was of importance, owing to the fact that the particle/interface interaction may be used to guide the particle motion. The ability to engineering the interaction is needed for computational materials design, drug delivery and lab-on-a-chip devices as well as the understanding of non-equilibrium thermodynamics and anomalous diffusion. The educational goal evolved around offering an interdisciplinary research environment to students from underrepresented groups at the City College of New York (CCNY).

For the accomplishment of these goals, three objectives were identified: (1) Use nanoscale molecular dynamics simulations and optical microscopy to study the approach of Brownian and Swimming patchy particles to a liquid/air interface. (2) Experimentally quantify patchy particle behavior near liquid/air and liquid/solid interfaces and simulate particle dynamics near interfaces at the mesoscale using Langevin equation methods. (3) Examine the role of atomistic force correlations on both symmetric and Janus particles in the presence of interfaces and during collisions, and assess their consequences for mesoscale modeling techniques such as Brownian dynamics and Fokker-Planck equations.

New Instrumentation and Techniques: Holographic microscopy was shown to be capable of tracking the orientation of Janus particles in bulk and near liquid/liquid interfaces. Two novel optical microscopy tracking procedures were developed that allow tracking of Janus particle orientation near a solid wall for fluorescent and non-fluorescent particles. Both methods are able to identify actual body centers and orientations of particles with resolutions of 0.5-pixel and angular uncertainty of sub-10°. An experimental setup has been build that enables measuring of swimming velocities and diffusion coefficients of active particles near liquid/liquid interfaces.

Research Findings and Outcomes: Molecular dynamics simulations were used to study the impact of surface curvature on the slip velocity and the coupling between translational and rotational motion. Further, MD simulations and experimental holographic microscopy were shown to yield very similar particle trajectories despite the three orders of magnitude particle size difference showing that MD simulations are a useful tool in the study of actively swimming and Brownian Janus particles. Continuum hydrodynamics have identified that solute accumulation near the wall is impacted by size of active area on the particle and orientation of the active area with respect to the boundary. Probability distributions of skimming time, positional fluctuations and angular orientations in skimming and stationary configurations for self-propelled particles near solid interfaces were determined leading to a phase diagram for particle swimmers near a liquid/solid interface. A general outcome of the study is that particle/interface interactions can be engineered to guide the motion of particles in the absence of an on-board guiding system.

Educational Impact: The grant provided research opportunities for two HS, six undergraduate, two MS, and five PhD students in the Chemical Engineering program at the City College of New York. Students were trained to make Janus particles, learned to code tracking software, used Molecular Dynamics and Brownian simulations with the goal to better understand the behavior of asymmetric particles near liquid/solid and fluid/fluid interfaces. Support of this project provided a year-round mentoring program for CCNY undergraduate and MS students from underrepresented groups. Nine students (five summer students) from underrepresented groups met with the PI on a weekly basis to discuss academic progress, career plans, graduate school applications and research opportunities. Six undergraduate students and two MS students participated in the mentoring program of whom ~50% have moved on into MS and PhD programs.
